11.37.text:
so they occur all around us all the time,
even if we don’t see them

15.07.text:
and therefore they're very likely
to be involved in a crime scene

18.07.text:
whether just accidentally or actually
because they have moved there

23.10.text: in response to some element of the crime scene.

26.33.text:
Looking at the body itself
it will be the pathologist

29.07.text:
who would look at the changes
in the body and try to determine

32.40.text: from the body what the post-mortem interval is.

34.80.text: But as an entomologist I can help the pathologist

37.63.text:
by looking, not at the body, but at
the insects that are feeding on and around the body.

43.03.text:
More precisely we are determining
a minimum post-mortem interval,

46.70.text:
that's basically the period that
the first insects found the body after death.

52.27.text:
Ordinarily in the summer months
in the UK with a body outdoors

57.27.text: it would be colonised by insects within 12 or 24 hours.

61.80.text: At the crime scene the main thing is recovery of evidence

66.10.text:
and I’ll do that at the scene
and then go back to the post-mortem

69.77.text: and carry on there if necessary.

73.40.text: We're interested not just on the insects on the body

76.33.text: but on insects that have been feeding on the body

78.47.text: and may already have dispersed away,

80.77.text:
because it makes good sense for these insects,
once they finish feeding,

84.60.text: not to hang around on the body because some other scavenger

87.17.text: may come and consume them as well as the body,

90.17.text: so they tend to disperse away.

92.77.text:
The gold standard forensic indicators are blowflies
and these are the ones that come in first,

97.63.text: immediately after the body's dead and starts to decompose.

102.07.text: They have an incredible sense of smell

105.20.text: and will arrive very, very quickly after death.

109.60.text:
The female fly will lay between
150 to 200 eggs on the suitable substrate,

115.47.text: and a human body is absolutely ideal for that.

118.60.text: Within about 24 hours in the UK summer

122.07.text:
those eggs will hatch and
they'll hatch into first stage larvae,

126.33.text: and these larvae are tiny, 1.5mm long.

130.60.text: Those larvae, though, are very hungry,

133.23.text:
they will crawl into the recesses
of the body and start feeding.

136.73.text:
Within 24 hours they themselves moult
into the second stage maggot

141.07.text: and then about another 24 hours later,

143.43.text: those will moult into the final, third stage maggot.

146.30.text: And that will feed for about three or four days.

149.50.text: When it's finished feeding it disperses away from the body

153.40.text: and looks for somewhere to pupate,

158.03.text:
It begins to harden itself and darken itself
until it forms a rugby ball shaped pupariam,

165.03.text: and inside that pupa the larval tissues are reassembled

169.53.text: through metamorphosis into an adult fly,

172.03.text: it’s a quite remarkable process that amazes me even today.

176.77.text:
After about 10 days in the UK summer
the adult fly is now ready to emerge.

182.50.text: And so the life cycle continues.

189.13.text: When blowflies respond to the odours of decomposition

193.30.text: they tend to navigate their way upwind through the odour plume

197.77.text: until they arrive at the scene.

200.37.text:
They will then use their visual
cues to land on the body

204.23.text:
and to move around and look for
the most suitable egg-laying site.

208.63.text:
Eggs are very susceptible to desiccation
so they tend to choose areas

212.73.text:
where the humidity is higher so
that tends to be the body orifices,

216.70.text: the eyes, the nose, the mouth,

219.10.text: and the genital/anal orifices if those are exposed.

223.57.text: And of course the humidity is maintained in those environments

228.10.text:
but it also affords the larvae the
opportunity to crawl into the body

232.67.text: and feed on the internal tissues,

236.03.text:
which are less well protected from
the insects' enzyme activity

240.47.text:
than the hard, tough, outer skin
that normally covers our bodies.

246.10.text:
So the focus of blowfly colonisation
tends to be on the head orifices.

260.67.text:
In this image just coming up here
we have a stillborn piglet.

264.27.text:
All you can see at the moment is the hotspot
and you can see a fly that’s just landed on it there.

270.60.text:
Surprisingly, although they’re coldblooded,
flies themselves generate quite a bit of heat

275.50.text: through their flight activity and muscle activity.

279.77.text:
The pig outline now is formed because
we’ve adjusted the temperature range

284.13.text: and you can see there’s a couple of flies moving around there.

287.23.text: We know they’re not the first flies to have found this piglet

289.63.text:
because that hotspot there is in fact where
there is already a small maggot mass developing.

298.03.text:
And what you can do actually is you can take
a series of images over a timescale from,

304.50.text:
in this case it was from day one to fourteen,
so a couple of weeks period.

309.30.text:
In the first six days or so, not a lot’s happening
because it takes a while for these first flies

315.57.text:
that have come in on day one to
lay their eggs, for the eggs to hatch.

319.27.text: - this was during a winter period.

321.40.text:
But on day six the temperature starts
to go up in the mouth of the pig

325.57.text:
and then over successive days that temperature hotspot
moves down through the body of the piglet

332.50.text: as its being consumed basically by a larval mass

336.07.text:
which is just rolling from the front end
to the back end of the piglet.

340.10.text:
And then after two weeks the piglet
is now completely cold and empty.

345.67.text:
All of the maggots have finished
feeding and they’ve moved away.

353.23.text:
So one of the accessibility issues we’ve been exploring
at the museum just in the last few months

357.77.text: is the impact of putting a body in a suitcase.

362.53.text: Is it possible for flies to find a body in a suitcase?

367.57.text:
Well, we found that using pig heads
as surrogate bodies from a butchers shop,

371.73.text: just pop them into a normal, carry-on suitcase

375.17.text:
and they delay the arrival of the flies
by one to three days or more,

381.20.text: However, the flies will arrive at the suitcase,

384.33.text: and they know that there’s a body in there.

386.57.text: And they will actually oviposit through the zip,

389.80.text: which most suitcases are sealed with these days.

393.67.text: The eggs will be laid into the suitcase

396.20.text: and in fact if they're just scattered around the zip

398.33.text:
the larvae themselves when they hatch
can crawl and enter the suitcase.

402.57.text:
So even hiding a body in a suitcase
won’t stop flies finding it

407.10.text:
and once they’ve found it they
will feed on the body in there.

410.70.text:
And in fact they will then try
to actually exit the suitcase as well,

415.20.text: and they can do this often through the holes in the frame

418.13.text: where the wheels of the suitcase are found.

420.53.text: So there's a whole range of factors out there in the environment

423.77.text: and even in the human factors of the environment

429.47.text: and make it a real challenge for a forensic entomologist
